entry.title: SAP Fiori development newsletter July 2025 (issue #35)
entry.content:
Summer is here, bringing hot weather across the U.S. and around the world. SAP is also turning up the temperature with hot new AI-powered innovations, many of which were introduced at Sapphire (see article below). Even more new stuff is planned for TechEd and Devtoberfest in the fall.

For ongoing updates, I encourage you to join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable. You can meet online with fellow developers and the SAP engineers who build our professional development tools. Register online or email me for an invitation. Our next meeting is Wednesday, July 9, 2025. 

If you prefer to receive this in your inbox, please subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter.

Development News

Sapphire had great innovations, if you are on public cloud

There were lots of announcements about new innovations for both developers and business users. The question for many customers is when their systems will be current enough to consume them. Read about the two parallel universes ‚Äì one filled with AI in the cloud and the other grounded in legacy code.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/parallel-universes-the-dual-nature-of-ux-and-ai-among-sap-customers-at/ba-p/14113975

SAP Fiori tools 2506 now available

The 2506 release of SAP Fiori tools includes enhancements that make full-stack development with SAP Fiori elements and RAP even more seamless‚Äîfrom initial app creation to UI adaptation and low-code configuration.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-tools-2506-update-open-source-faster-app-creation-adaptation/ba-p/14131156

AI-powered project accelerator

The AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools automates multiple steps, including creating a data model, preparing mock data, building an OData service, generating an SAP Fiori app and adding the necessary annotations. See how to set up a trial account and try it for yourself.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/from-idea-to-app-using-ai-powered-project-accelerator-to-develop-sap-fiori/ba-p/14095300

Introducing SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

We have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-sapui5-version-preview-in-sap-build-work-zone/ba-p/14117996

Explore SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free for future-proof UI5 apps

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. Test your code for future-proof best practices and provide early feedback to the UI5 team.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/explore-sapui5-openui5-1-136-x-legacy-free/ba-p/14103271

SAPUI5 is leading the way in accessibility with WCAG 2.2

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards ensures that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sapui5-is-leading-the-way-in-accessibility-with-wcag-2-2/ba-p/14101596

SAP Fiori Application Generator available in open source

The SAP Fiori tools team is delighted to announce that the underlying code for the SAP Fiori Application Generator has been moved entirely to open source. This has been a long journey...
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-application-generator-available-in-open-source/ba-p/14109021

New SAP Design System portal for SAP Fiori design guidelines

The SAP Design System portal contains everything about the design system, including comprehensive new UI Kits for designers in Figma.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-sap-design-system-portal-for-sap-fiori-design-guidelines-and-new-ui/ba-p/14109558

Quickly generate and deploy SAP Fiori apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

The new quick SAP Fiori application generator lets you generate an application based on SAP Fiori elements annotations and deploy the SAP Fiori UI with only a few clicks from the service binding editor in ADT.
https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/quickly-generate-and-deploy-sap-fiori-apps-from-abap-development-tools-for/ba-p/14116822

Events

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Bangalore 

The biggest SAP Fiori Innovation Day ever!
This summary highlights the key sessions, insights from our presentations, and the remarkable contributions from our local development community.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-innovation-day-bangalore-connection-gratitude-ai-and-local/ba-p/14129580

If you are a partner, please let me know if you are interested in sponsoring in one or both of our locations.
I hope you can join us.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP ‚Äì Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn‚Äôt enough,‚ÄØSAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the‚ÄØSAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video‚ÄØdemo (starting at 0:08) ‚ÄØfor more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05) ‚ÄØfor more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems‚ÄØin SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can‚ÄØ centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • SAP BTP Talk Podcast: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Valuehelp docu - It‚Äôs just the old wine in a new bottle ‚Äì but then, every bottle has its day! üòâ
entry.content:
With SAPUI5 1.138, the SAP Fiori elements OData V4 ‚ÄúField Help‚Äù documentation has undergone a complete revamp! It‚Äôs essentially the same contents but with a much better restructuring of the key topics. The flow of topics is a lot more natural and in sync with the way the field help shows up in the UI ‚Äì resulting in a far better readability of the topic.

So in this short article, let us see what are the key elements of the new structure. This is NOT a deep dive into the field help (or valuehelp) topic ‚Äì the official documentation is already doing that! But instead we shall take a closer look at what are the key parts of a field help or value help and where in the documentation we can find this information!

First up is the Field Help page.

This was way too bloated in the older version ‚Äì you can see it here! The newer version is a lot leaner and includes only the different field helps that can be configured for a fe V4 field. In addition, it retains the section on using the ‚ÄúHistory of Recently Entered Values‚Äù feature but also brings in a nice little section on using the Type-Ahead support!

The Value Help is now big enough to get its own page! So, what is covered here?

One big help is that now all value help related annotations are centralized in this page. A developer can take one quick look into this and easily figure out all the annotations that are supported for configuration of a value help. The XML and CAP CDS annotations match perfectly and hopefully soon we can also bring in the equivalent ABAP CDS annotations!

Most of the contents that were specific to valuehelp dialog are now pushed out of this page making this much leaner and easier to do a full page scan to understand the overall concept w/o getting lost with all the details!

Value Help Dialog

The many nuances of the value help dialog has now found its own home and page! The page describes in clear simple language the configurations required for each part of the dialog ‚Äì starting from the title and then covering all other parts like the search bar, the filter bar, the ‚Äúvariants‚Äù of the value helps and finally the main table that shows the value help data! The Text/TextArrangement topic is very much simplified now and can be read w/o additional caffeine üòä

A cool small little section is dedicated to the ‚ÄúCaching‚Äù behavior and even links an example showing how cache can be refreshed, where needed!

And finally, we get to see a nice screenshot and a table showing why the Define Condition never comes up the same for any two fields üòä

The last two chapters (dropdown and In/Out mappings) are largely the same as before and I expect some revisions here in the upcoming versions!

Conclusion

The goal was to make value help documentation a much simpler and clearer articulation of the underlying capability and by and large, I believe, this is now achieved. There are still of course some improvements and tweaks to be added and hopefully we get over that soon. Until then, I hope you have a good time configuring your value helps and yes, please add a comment if you see potential for further improvements/simplification! Thank you!

Cheers,

   Sandeep

entry.title: Developing a Shell Plugin for SAP Build Work Zone to Display Custom Notifications on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction‚ÄÉ

Unlocking Custom Experiences in SAP Build Work Zone: Shell Plugin in Action
In today‚Äôs digital workplace, personalization is key. This article showcases how to enhance SAP Build Work Zone with a custom shell plugin that brings tailored notifications right to the user‚Äôs fingertips. Using a Multi-Target UI5/CAP application, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to create, manage, and surface custom alerts‚Äîseamlessly integrated into your Work Zone experience.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To replicate this you should have a base knowledge of SAP BTP, JS, SAPUI5 and SAP CAP, I will not go deep down in to how to generate a project in BAS, or create an instance in SAP BTP. 

***GITHUB URL REMOVED BY MODERATION***

Project Architecture

‚ÄÉ

Backend/Frontend App Development:

Generate a regular SAP CAP application

Firstly I've created a primitave data structure under db/schema.cds

namespace my.Notification;

entity Notification {
    key ID : UUID;
    type: String(30);
    title: String;
    message: String;
}

 Than a service at srv/service.cds:

using { my.Notification as my } from '../db/schema';

service NotificationService {
    entity Notification as projection on my.Notification;
}

And the backend is almost done, now add an app router and a sapui5 freestyle base app to the project.

Now let's add a form to create and delete the notifications under app/<app name>/webapp/view/<view name>.view.xml:

 

Spoiler
Remember to correct the controller name if you copy the code

 

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:form="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">

    <Toolbar>
        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
    </Toolbar>

    <Shell id="mainShell">
        <VBox class="sapUiSmallMargin">
            <form:SimpleForm
                    editable="true"
                    layout="ResponsiveGridLayout"
                    labelSpanL="1" labelSpanM="2"
                    adjustLabelSpan="false"
                    columnsL="3" columnsM="3"
                    class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">

                    <Label text="Type" />
                    <ComboBox id="newType" selectedKey="information">
                        <core:Item key="Warning" text="Warning" />
                        <core:Item key="Success" text="Success" />
                        <core:Item key="Information" text="Information" />
                        <core:Item key="Error" text="Error" />
                        <core:Item key="Alert" text="Alert" />
                        <core:Item key="Confirm" text="Confirm" />
                    </ComboBox>

                    <Label text="Title" />
                    <Input id="newTitle" />

                    <Label text="Message" />
                    <Input id="newMessage" />

                    <Label text="" />
                    <Button text="Add Notification"
                        press="onAddNotification"
                        type="Emphasized"/>
                </form:SimpleForm>

            <!-- Table Section -->
            <Table id="shellNotificationsTable" items="{/Notification}">
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Delete" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Type" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Title" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Message" />
                    </Column>
                </columns>

                <items>
                    <ColumnListItem>
                        <cells>
                            <Button icon="sap-icon://delete" type="Negative" press="deleteRow" />
                            <Text text="{type}" />
                            <Text text="{title}" />
                            <Text text="{message}" />
                        </cells>
                    </ColumnListItem>
                </items>
            </Table>
        </VBox>
    </Shell>
</mvc:View>

As next let's implement the controller that manages the view with all the necessary notification creation/deletion methods:

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/m/MessageBox",
	"sap/m/MessageToast"
], (Controller, MessageBox, MessageToast) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView", {
        onInit() {

        },

        deleteRow: function (oEvent) {
			var oContext = oEvent.getSource().getBindingContext().getObject();
			console.log(oContext);
			MessageBox.confirm("Are your sure you want to delete this message?", {
				title: "Confirm",
				onClose: function (sAction) {
					if (sAction === "OK") {
						this.onDeleteSpecificRecord(oContext)
					}
				}.bind(this),
				actions: [
					MessageBox.Action.OK,
					MessageBox.Action.CANCEL
				],
				emphasizedAction: MessageBox.Action.OK
			})
		},

		onDeleteSpecificRecord: function (oRecord) {
			var oDataModel = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel();
			var oBusyDialog = new sap.m.BusyDialog({
				title: "Deleting Record",
				text: "Please Wait ..."
			})
			oBusyDialog.open();
			oDataModel.delete(`/Notification('${oRecord.ID}')`)
				.then(() => {
					console.log("Record deleted successfully");
				})
				.catch((error) => {
					console.error("Deletion failed:", error);
				})
				.finally(() => {
					this.getView().byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").refresh();
					oBusyDialog.close();
				});
		},

		onAddNotification: function () {
			const sType = this.byId("newType").getValue();
			const sTitle = this.byId("newTitle").getValue();
			const sMessage = this.byId("newMessage").getValue();

			this.byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").create({
				"type": sType,
				"title": sTitle,
				"message": sMessage
			}).created().then(function() {
				MessageToast.show("Created")
			})
		}
    });
});

The last thing to do is to add all the features that you need to the application, like HANA DB, xsuaa in my case, to do so just run

cds add hana
cds add xsuaa

And like this is the app ready, let's deploy it, firstly login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

then right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"

then go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

BTP Steps

To connect to the app from the shell plugin you need to create a SAP BTP Destination, 

to do so go to <BTP Subaccount> -> Cloud Foundry -> <Your space> -> <Your app name>-srv and copy it's address, that's your destination URL

Now you need to get the authentication data for the Destination

Go to <Your CF Space> -> Instances -> <Your app name>-auth -> <Your app name>-auth-key 

Copy these:

Client ID, Client secret and url (Access Token URL)

Now go back to your Subaccount and create a new destination with your data:

  • URL:  app-srv URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • ClientID: ClientID
  • Client secret: Client secret
  • Token service URL type: Dedicated
  • Token Service URL: <Access token URL>/oauth/token

After this add these 2 parameters:

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
  • WebIDEEnabled: true

With this step is the backend development concluded.

Shell Plugin Development:

Firstly a general explanation about shell plugins. Shell Plugins are UI5 Applications that allow to add new Elements to SAP Build Work Zone/Fiori Launchpad like Headers, Footers, menu items etc.

To create a shell plugin generate a plain UI5 Basic Freestyle application with the "Template Wizard" in Business Application Studio.

There are a couple of things to modify in the manifest.json to make a a Shell Plugin:

Inside sap.app change the type to component:

"type": "component"

In sap.app>crossNavigation hide the launcher:

"crossNavigation": {
      "inbounds": {
        "Shell-plugin": {
          "semanticObject": "Shell",
          "action": "plugin",
          "title": "{{Shell-plugin.flpTitle}}",
          "hideLauncher": true,
          "icon": "",
          "signature": {
            "parameters": {},
            "additionalParameters": "allowed"
          }
        }
      }
    },

 Add this part under after sap.cloud:

"sap.flp": {
    "type": "plugin"
  }

  This way the Shell Plugin configuration is completed, now let's add our newly created Destination

in sap.app>dataSources add this:

"NotificationService": {
        "uri": "/ShellNotifications/odata/v4/notification/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }

and in sap.ui5>models: 

"Notification": {
        "dataSource": "NotificationService",
        "settings": {
          "synchronizationMode": "None",  
          "operationMode": "Server",
          "autoExpandSelect": true
        },
        "type": "sap.ui.model.odata.v4.ODataModel"
      }

and as last thing add this route to your xs-app.json file:

 

Spoiler
Remember: the order of the routes in xs-app matters, if you add it at the end it might not be resolved correctly by the app router

 

{
      "source": "^/ShellNotifications/(.*)$",
      "destination": "ShellNotifications",
      "target": "$1",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
      "csrfProtection": true
    },

Now finally you can add the code that displays the notifications, to do so open the Component.js file and add the following code to the init method:

const oModel = this.getModel("Notification");

            oModel.bindList("/Notification").requestContexts().then((aContexts) => {
                const aData = aContexts.map(oContext => oContext.getObject());
                for (const el of aData) {
                    const nType = el["type"];
                    const nTitle = el["title"];
                    const nMessage = el["message"]
                    if (nType === "Information") {
                        MessageBox.information(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        });
                    } else if (nType === "Alert") {
                        MessageBox.alert(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Confirm") {
                        MessageBox.confirm(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Error") {
                        MessageBox.error(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Success") {
                        MessageBox.success(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Warning") {
                        MessageBox.warning(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    }
                }
            }).catch((err) => {
                console.error("Failed to load notifications:", err);
            });

 And like this is the development finished, the last step is to deploy it and add to WorkZone.

To build it do the same steps as with the MTA app:

  • right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"
  • go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

SAP Build Work Zone Steps

Although the SAP Build Work Zone standard and advanced edition have some UI differences, the steps are the same for both of them.

All the steps performed below are done on SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition.

Start by going to the Administration Console -> External Integration -> Business Content -> Content Manager

‚ÄÉThan open the content channel and update the "HTML5 Apps"

‚ÄÉAfter that go Content Explorer and click Content Explorer (In the current UI it's a button in the header)

Select "HTML5 Apps" and add the new Shell Plugin that you just created

‚ÄÉTo be able to see the plugin, assign it to a role, in my case it's the "Everyone" role, you can find it in the Content Manager

‚ÄÉAfter you've done that you should be able to see your new shell plugin the SAP Build Work Zone's launchpad

‚ÄÉIf you don't see it try to open the page in an "Anonymous" Tab and check the developer console

Conclusion

What we‚Äôve built here is just a glimpse into what‚Äôs possible with shell plugins in SAP Build Work Zone. By integrating a custom notification system, we‚Äôve shown how easily you can extend the platform to better fit your customers‚Äô needs. But this is only the starting point.

There‚Äôs a wide range of enhancements you can explore next‚Äîsuch as targeting specific users with personalized notifications, adding actionable buttons to each alert, or even integrating with external systems to trigger real-time messages. The flexibility of shell extensions offers endless opportunities to enrich the Work Zone experience and tailor it to your organization‚Äôs workflows.

So go ahead‚Äîexperiment, extend, and elevate your Work Zone.

entry.title: The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code
entry.content:
In the past I‚Äôve had to implement actions in SAPUI5 every now and then. Because I mostly work with Fiori elements now, hand-coding actions has become a rare task for me ‚Äî and whenever I do need to do it, the official docs are pretty thin and the code samples are sparse.

With this post (and a CAP sample project) I want to walk you through the process ‚Äî and leave a note to my future self ‚Äî on how to wire up actions in SAPUI5.

What exactly are ‚Äúactions‚Äù and ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù?

Both Actions and Functions are service operations defined in OData / CAP that go beyond the standard CRUD verbs:

Concept

Side effects

Return type

Typical use case

Action

Yes (write)

void / entity / collection

Update price, approve a request

Function

No (read-only)

scalar / entity / collection

Calculate price, fetch KPIs

In CAP there are two scopes for both actions and functions:

  • Bound ‚Äî tied to a single instance or collection of an entity.Unbound ‚Äî defined at service level, usable anywhere.

Quick Start

git clone https://github.com/marianfoo/ui5-call-action.git
cd ui5-call-action
npm install          # installs CAP, UI5 tooling, etc.
npm run deploy        # deploys the service to the sqlite database
npm run watch           # starts CAP + FE/Freestyle apps

Open in your browser http://localhost:4004:

  • UI5 V4 Fiori elements ‚Üí /com.marianzeis.books

  • UI5 V2 Fiori elements ‚Üí /com.marianzeis.booksv2

  • UI5 V4 Freestyle ‚Üí /com.freestyle

  • UI5 V2 Freestyle ‚Üí /com.freestyle-v2

 

Implementing actions in CAP

I‚Äôve put together a classic Bookshop example and sprinkled in a handful of actions.
Full repo: github.com/marianfoo/ui5-call-action

Bound actions

Action

What it does

Parameters

promoteBook

Promote a book

‚Äî

setDiscount

Apply a discount

percentage, reason

halfPrice

Cut price in half

‚Äî

addChapter

Add a chapter

title, pages

massHalfPrice

Half price for multiple books

books[]

Unbound actions

Action

What it does

Parameters

refreshCatalog

Refresh catalog

‚Äî

generateReport

Generate report

type, dateFrom, dateTo

createBooksAndChapters

Bulk create books + chapters

books[] and chapters[] (deep parameter)

Functions (read-only)

Function

Scope

Description

getCurrentPrice

bound

Return current book price

getSumBookPrices

unbound

Sum of all book prices

Definitions ‚Üí srv/bookshop-service.cds
Handlers ‚Üí srv/bookshop-service.js

OData V2 quick note

CAP speaks OData V4 out-of-the-box. To expose an OData V2 endpoint, install @cap-js-community/odata-v2-adapter. The service will be reachable at:

http://localhost:4004/odata/v2/bookshop

SAPUI5 via annotations

The smoothest route in UI5 is Fiori elements. Just add an annotation and the button appears. Example for promoteBook. :

{
  $Type: 'UI.DataFieldForAction',
  Label: 'CAP Promote Book',
  Action: 'BookshopService.promoteBook'
}

The actions are now visible in the table header. The buttons with the prefix ‚ÄòCAP‚Äô are defined with the annotation, the buttons with the prefix ‚ÄòCUST‚Äô are custom actions defined and implemented in the frontend.

 

SAPUI5 with custom code

To compare APIs I created two freestyle apps and two Fiori elements apps:

App

Tech

Key APIs

/app/freestyle

OData V4, TypeScript

invoke(), execute()

/app/freestyle-v2

OData V2, TypeScript

callFunction()

/app/books, /app/books-v2

Fiori elements

invokeAction() / invokeActions()

OData V4 freestyle app

Controller ‚Üí MainView.controller.ts

// Legacy pattern
const actionBinding = odataModel.bindContext(
  "BookshopService.promoteBook(...)",
  bookContext
);
await actionBinding.execute();

// Modern pattern
await actionBinding.invoke();

Collection Bound Actions

The action "massHalfPrice" is a so called Collection-Bound Action only for V4. The documentation about this is very sparse.
In capire you can find samples about the implementation in CAP: Actions & Functions / Bound Actions and Functions
In the UI5 Documentation it looks like it is described under "Static Action".
It was not easy to figure out how to call from the frontend and i was not the only one how asked this.
Basically, I see the action as a normal bound action that has the type Books as an input parameter. Accordingly, the call in the front end is the same, only the path to call in frontend is slightly different.

Definition in the CAP App

  entity Books as projection on my.Books actions {
    //bound to the collection and not a specific instance of Books
    action massHalfPrice (books: many $self) returns array of Books;
    // bound action with one book as parameter
    action similarBooks (book: $self) returns array of Books;
  };
//unbound action with many books as parameter
action massHalfPrice (books: many Books) returns array of Books;

metadata of three different actions in V4
Top Bound Collection-Bound Action // Middle Bound Action with one Book as parameter  // Bottom Unbound Collection-Bound Action

<Action Name="massHalfPrice" IsBound="true" EntitySetPath="books">
<Parameter Name="books" Type="Collection(BookshopService.Books)" Nullable="true"/>
<ReturnType Type="Collection(BookshopService.Books)"/>
</Action>
<Action Name="similarBooks" IsBound="true" EntitySetPath="book">
<Parameter Name="book" Type="BookshopService.Books"/>
<ReturnType Type="Collection(BookshopService.Books)"/>
</Action>
<Action Name="massHalfPrice" IsBound="false">
<Parameter Name="books" Type="Collection(BookshopService.Books)" Nullable="true"/>
<ReturnType Type="Collection(BookshopService.Books)"/>
</Action>

Call from the UI5 OData V4 Freestyle App to call Bound Collection Action

public async invokeMassHalfPrice(): Promise<void> {
    const odataModel = this.getView()?.getModel() as ODataModel;
    const actionPath = "/Books/BookshopService.massHalfPrice(...)";
    // Get existing books from the model instead of creating dummy data
    // Here we use the binding parameter approach - binding to existing collection data
    const table = this.byId("booksTable") as Table;
    const binding = table.getBinding("items");
    const booksData = binding.getContexts().map(context => {
        const bookObject = context.getObject();
        return {
            ID: bookObject.ID,
            IsActiveEntity: bookObject.IsActiveEntity
        };
    });
    const actionBinding = odataModel.bindContext(actionPath);
    actionBinding.setParameter("books", booksData);
    await actionBinding.invoke();
}

 

OData V2 freestyle app

Controller ‚Üí MainView.controller.ts

const data = await new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  model.callFunction("/Books_promoteBook", {
    method: "POST",
    urlParameters: { ID: bookId, IsActiveEntity: true },
    success: resolve,
    error: reject
  });
});

Paths differ:

  • V4 ‚Üí BookshopService.promoteBook(...)

  • V2 ‚Üí /Books_promoteBook

 

Custom code in Fiori elements (V4 & V2)

Fiori elements already renders ‚ÄúCAP‚Äù buttons for every annotated action, but you can go further and add CUST logic without leaving the Fiori elements shell. All you need is an ext/controller/*.ts|js file and manifest.json metadata that points to it. Inside that controller you work with ExtensionAPI:

  • getEditFlow().invokeAction() ‚Äî V4 helper that wraps OData calls, busy indicators, draft handling, side-effects and messaging.

  • extensionAPI.invokeActions() ‚Äî classic V2 helper (still available, multi-select aware).

Below is a stripped-down version of the demo controller Action.ts (V4) / ListReportExt.controller.js (V2). Notice how the pattern is always the same: pick the selected contexts, call invokeAction(), pass parameters if needed.

OData V4

// 1) Bound action WITHOUT parameters
export async function customPromoteBook(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  const ctx = this.getSelectedContexts();
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("BookshopService.promoteBook", {
    contexts: ctx
  });
}

// 2) Bound action WITH parameters
export async function customSetDiscount(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  const ctx = this.getSelectedContexts();
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("BookshopService.setDiscount", {
    contexts: ctx,
    parameterValues: [
      { name: "percentage", value: 15 },
      { name: "reason",     value: "HOLIDAY_SALE" }
    ]
  });
}

// 3) Unbound action WITHOUT parameters
export async function customRefreshCatalog(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("refreshCatalog", {
    model: this.getModel()
  });
}

// 4) Unbound action WITH parameters
export async function customGenerateReport(this: ExtensionAPI) {
  await this.getEditFlow().invokeAction("generateReport", {
    model: this.getModel(),
    parameterValues: [
      { name: "reportType", value: "sales" },
      { name: "dateFrom",   value: "2024-01-01" },
      { name: "dateTo",     value: "2024-12-31" }
    ]
  });
}

OData V2

/**
 * 1. Bound action WITHOUT parameters - using invokeActions
 */
customPromoteBookInvoke: async function() {
    const contexts = this.extensionAPI.getSelectedContexts();     // Get selected rows
    await this.extensionAPI.invokeActions("/Books_promoteBook", contexts);
}
/**
 * 2. Bound action WITH parameters - using invokeActions
 */
customSetDiscountInvoke: async function() {
    const contexts = this.extensionAPI.getSelectedContexts();
    const parameters = { 
        percentage: 15, 
        reason: "HOLIDAY_SALE" 
    };
    await this.extensionAPI.invokeActions("/Books_setDiscount", contexts, parameters);
}
/**
 * 3. Unbound action WITHOUT parameters - using invokeActions
 */
customRefreshCatalogInvoke: async function() {
    try {
        await this.extensionAPI.invokeActions("/refreshCatalog");
        MessageToast.show("Catalog refreshed successfully");
    } catch (error) {
        MessageToast.show("Failed to refresh catalog: " + (error.message || "Unknown error"));
    }
}
/**
 * 4. Unbound action WITH parameters - using invokeActions
 */
customGenerateReportInvoke: async function() {
    const parameters = {
        reportType: "sales",
        dateFrom: "2024-01-01",
        dateTo: "2024-12-31"
    };
    const result = await this.extensionAPI.invokeActions("/generateReport", null, parameters);
}

Why bother?

  • Quickly add dialogs, parameter defaults, or pre/post-processing logic without touching the backend.

  • Framework handles draft save, busy state and message pop-ups for you.

  • One handler works for multi-select (just pass an array of contexts).

  • You can mix CAP-generated buttons and CUST buttons side-by-side to compare approaches.

Fiori elements API

Supports

Recommended for

getEditFlow().invokeAction()

Bound + Unbound actions, parameters, V4

Modern Draft-aware V4 apps

extensionAPI.invokeActions()

Bound + Unbound actions, multi-select, V2

Classic V2 List Report/Object Page

That‚Äôs the entire toolbox for custom code inside Fiori elements ‚Äî no need to switch to freestyle unless you want total UI freedom. Jump into the repo, press the CUST * buttons and check the dev-tools network tab to see each API in action.

API decision matrix 

Scenario

Recommended API

Why

Fiori elements V4

CAP annotations or invokeAction()

Auto buttons, framework busy-handling

Fiori elements V2

CAP annotations + extensionAPI.invokeActions()

Multi-select, side-effects, Fiori elements only API

Freestyle V4

bindContext().invoke()

Modern Promise API (requires UI5 1.123+)

Freestyle V4

bindContext().execute()

available since 1.37, deprecated in 1.123; keeps working for backward compatibility

Freestyle V2

ODataModel.callFunction()

no deep parameters, no collection-bound action

Rule of thumb ‚Äî start with annotations for business logic, move to custom controller code only where UI-specific behavior is needed.

That‚Äôs it! Clone the repo, start cds watch, and explore each app to see the different APIs in action. 

Also, create a Pull Request or Issue if a sample implementation is missing to complete the Guide!

entry.title: CAP‚Äëify UI5: Auto‚ÄëLoading UI5¬†Tooling Extensions the CAP Plug‚Äëin Way
entry.content:
I was back at Code Connect this year, first enjoying UI5con and then diving straight into reCAP. Both parts of the event were packed with sharp sessions and brilliant people ‚Äì if you were there, you know the vibe.

Why CAP plug‚Äëins made me jealous

During the reCAP tracks I kept noticing how effortlessly SAP Cloud Application Programming Model  plug‚Äëins integrate: install the package, let the plug‚Äëin declare its events, and the framework picks it up ‚Äì zero YAML, zero boilerpla

In his keynote @pmuessig  demoed something similar for UI5: a flag --rte for ui5-tooling-modules. It triggers an npm postinstall script that writes the module into ui5.yaml, so you can use it right away. Nice ‚Äì but my dream is the next step: UI5 tooling extensions that behave like CAP plug‚Äëins and ‚Äújust work‚Äù after npm install.

Enter ui5-plugin-loader ‚Äì a Proof of Concept (PoC)

That idea wouldn‚Äôt leave me alone, so ‚Äì still sitting in the Audimax while listening to reCAP Sessions ‚Äì I hacked together a proof of concept: ui5‚Äëplugin‚Äëloader(npmjs / GitHub Repo).

Disclaimer: The loader is a proof of concept, written for exploration. It‚Äôs not production‚Äëready and doesn‚Äôt match the polish of official extensions. Also 100% vibe-coded with ChatGPT and Cursor and claude-4.

What the PoC currently does

  • Scans package.json for UI5 tooling extensions.
  • Loads them in a predictable order (stringreplace ‚Üí transpile ‚Üí modules ‚Üí livereload ‚Üí rest).
  • Applies sensible defaults, yet lets you disable or override anything via ui5.yaml.
  • Provides fallback manifests for common extensions that do not ship their own.

How it works under the hood

Schema‚Äëdriven defaults  
Each extension can ship a ui5-plugin-loader.json that follows a tiny JSON schema. If it does, the loader reads defaults straight from the package. For extensions that don‚Äôt, fallback manifests live in the loader itself.

Ordering  
The same schema lets an extension say ‚Äúrun me before X‚Äù or ‚Äúafter Y‚Äù. The algorithm is simple ‚Äì good enough for demos, not bullet‚Äëproof for mission‚Äëcritical builds.

No public runtime API  
UI5 Tooling 4.0 lacks an official way to register middleware or tasks on the fly, so the loader requires each package directly, calls its factory, and chains the resulting Express handlers. A working hack ‚Äì but fragile.

Overriding in ui5.yaml

server:
  customMiddleware:
    - name: ui5-plugin-loader
      afterMiddleware: compression
      configuration:
        disable:
          - ui5-middleware-livereload
        override:
          ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware:
            configuration:
              debug: true
  • disable ‚Äì turns extensions off.
  • override ‚Äì patches order or configuration.

Does it run?

Yes. Clone the repo and run the sample app with npm start, and the console shows the loader discovering manifests, loading middlewares, and serving your app. Add or remove an extension in package.json, restart, and watch the chain rearrange itself.

‚ûú  sample-app git:(main) ‚úó npm start

> com.pluginloader@1.0.0 start
> ui5 serve --open index.html

info graph:helpers:ui5Framework Using SAPUI5 version: 1.136.3
info server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Starting UI5 Plugin Loader pipeline...
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Unknown configuration key 'configuration' - ignoring
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Unknown configuration key 'middlewareName' - ignoring
info server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Found manifest for ui5-tooling-transpile in fallback directory
info server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Found manifest for ui5-middleware-livereload in fallback directory
info server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Pipeline completed: 2 middleware, 1 tasks (2ms)
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Found 2 middleware configurations, but dynamic registration is not supported.
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader Please configure middleware statically in ui5.yaml using the discovered configurations:
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader   - name: ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader     afterMiddleware: compression
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader   - name: ui5-middleware-livereload
warn server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader     afterMiddleware: compression
info server:custom-middleware:ui5-plugin-loader UI5 Plugin Loader completed: registered 2 middlewares, 1 tasks
Server started
URL: http://localhost:8080

My UI5 Freestyle Typescript App generated with easy-ui5 works!

 

Real‚Äëworld value ‚Äì or not?

The PoC is handy for quick demo apps or internal prototypes where you want TypeScript, modules, and livereload without touching YAML. For serious projects you still end up fine‚Äëtuning ui5.yaml, and the loader cannot hide that complexity. Peter‚Äôs approach ‚Äì let each npm package update ui5.yaml during postinstall ‚Äì might remain the cleaner path until UI5 Tooling gains native plug‚Äëin discovery.

Another argument against relying on ui5‚Äëplugin‚Äëloader came from the UI5 Tooling team at this year‚Äôs UI5con (slides / livestream) . With UI5 CLI v5 (Roadmap) several widely used extensions could become part of the core: the transpile feature, ui5-tooling-modules and ui5-middleware-serveframework (according to the slide deck, even if it wasn‚Äôt stated outright).

Once these capabilities ship out of the box, projects will need fewer third‚Äëparty extensions and the related entries in ui5.yaml will largely disappear.

 

Questions for the community

  • Should UI5 Tooling grow native plug‚Äëin discovery?
  • Would a shared schema for default config help?
  • Do we need an official runtime registration API?
